newsitem.title: FRANCE: Besson recreates sci-fi world at Cannes gala.
newsitem.headline: Besson recreates sci-fi world at Cannes gala.

text.p: Luc Besson recreated the monster-filled universe of his science-fiction blockbuster "The Fifth Element" at the Cannes festival's opening gala, hiring a glass and steel hangar in the old harbour for a party which cost a reported $2 million.

In a throwback to the extravagant jamborees of Cannes' golden years in the 1950s and 60s, the hangar was graced on Wednesday night with a pyramid -- which opened up to reveal a rock band -- and hanging models of the film's flying cars while a blue planet floated overhead.

The 'enfant terrible' of French fashion, Jean-Paul Gaultier, paraded his costume designs for the $90-million movie on a catwalk to the film's deafening score. The score later accompanied a firework display in the bay of the Riviera resort.
"So noisy nobody could hear you boo," one critic had quipped of the film starring Bruce Willis and Gary Oldman.

At the festival's earlier opening ceremony, a quieter affair save for a 50-strong band of Senegalese drummers, French actress Jeanne Moreau led a tribute to ailing Italian master Michelangelo Antonioni.
The director was given a standing ovation when Vanessa Redgrave, who had starred in Antonioni's "La Notte", handed him a replica of the Golden Palm award which had been stolen from him.

Jury president Isabelle Adjani, also awarded a standing ovation, pledged to defend cinema as a guarantee of liberty -- a veiled reference to China's preventing Zhang Yimou from showing "Keep Cool" in Cannes, and to Iranian pressures on Abbas Kiarostami.

French Culture Minister Philippe Douste-Blazy missed the opening ceremony because he was still recovering in hospital after he was stabbed while campaigning for the May-June parliamentary election in the streets of Lourdes last Friday.

He sent a message to the gala guests saying he had done all he could to promote French cinema since he took office two years ago. Both Douste-Blazy and President Jacques Chirac are expected to attend Sunday's 50th anniversary gala sporting a bevvy of stars and past Golden Palm winners.
Hot on the heels of Michael Jackson, music will again hijack the Cannes festival on Friday when Britain's Spice Girls promote their next movie with the adventurous title: "Spice Girls: The Movie".
Richard E. Grant, who says he was bullied by his eight-year-old daughter into playing their manager, describes it as "'A Hard Day's Night' with bras".
